sections.purpose: To describe the standard operating procedure for the operation of Densitometer for accurate determination of density and specific gravity of liquids and solutions.
sections.scope: Applicable to density and specific gravity measurement activities carried out in the Central Instrumentation.
procedure: Ensure the instrument is placed on a stable surface away from direct sunlight and vibrations.
Power ON the densitometer and allow it to stabilize at the operating temperature.
Verify that the measurement cell is clean, dry, and free from any residues.
Calibrate the instrument using air and water or reference standards at the specified temperature.
Confirm that calibration results are within acceptable limits before proceeding.
Prepare the sample ensuring it is homogeneous and free from air bubbles.
If required, adjust the sample temperature to the specified value using a thermostat.
Rinse the measurement cell with a small portion of the sample to condition it.
Introduce the sample into the measurement cell using a syringe or pipette carefully.
Ensure complete filling of the cell with no trapped air bubbles in the measurement zone.
Allow the sample to equilibrate thermally within the cell until temperature is stable.
Initiate the measurement and wait for the reading to stabilize on the display.
Record the density value, temperature, and any other relevant parameters.
Perform duplicate or triplicate measurements to verify reproducibility.
After measurements, thoroughly clean the cell with appropriate solvents.
Rinse with distilled water and dry with filtered air or allow to air dry.
Perform an air check to ensure the cell is completely dry before storage.
Document all readings, temperature, and calculations in the analytical record.
precautions: Always perform calibration before use to ensure accuracy of measurements.
Maintain constant temperature during measurements as density is highly temperature-dependent.
Ensure samples are free from suspended particles and air bubbles.
Use filtered or degassed samples when necessary.
Clean the measurement cell thoroughly between different samples to avoid cross-contamination.
Use appropriate solvents that are compatible with the cell material.
Handle samples containing volatile or hazardous materials in a fume hood.
Do not use samples with viscosity exceeding the instrument specifications.
Verify cell integrity periodically for cracks or damage.
